description: From obsolete French rendition, alteration (after rendre (“to render”)) of reddition (“reddition”). Many senses influenced by render.

entries.meaning: An interpretation or performance of an artwork, especially a musical score or musical work. [from 19th c.]
examples: The group's debut, Beloved Symphony, featuring light opera renditions of Mozart, Bach and Chopin, was deemed insufficiently classic for inclusion on the classical charts.

entries.meaning: A given visual reproduction of something. [from 20th c.]
Translation between languages, or between forms of a language; a translated text or work. [from 17th c.]
(law, chiefly US) Formal deliverance of a verdict. [from 18th c.]
(law, chiefly US) The handing-over of someone wanted for justice who has fled a given jurisdiction; extradition. [from 19th c.]
examples: Since then, according to his lawyers and relatives, he has been repeatedly beaten, threatened with a firearm and with further rendition to Guantánamo by Ugandan officials, before being questioned by American officials.

entries.meaning: (now rare) The surrender (of a city, fortress etc.). [from 17th c.]
(now rare) The handing over of a person or thing. [from 17th c.]

verbs.description: rendition (third-person singular simple present renditions, present participle renditioning, simple past and past participle renditioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To surrender or hand over (a person or thing); especially, for one jurisdiction to do so to another.
